Regarding the woman from Aden who is the wife of my father Ahmad hin Yusuf abu Shaqar. I respectfully beg to state that last year, there was a house at Hura, which was suspected of 'being used for immoral purposes, where the said woman used to go frequently. We warned her not uo go there but she did noc. listen to us. She has a room on our main house which has a ’hadgir’ ( wind ventilator ) on the road side. On last Wednesday the wall of the ’hadgir* ( wind ventilator ) has been opened. This act and the fact that she has been entering the aforesaid house made us to suspect that she was of immoral character. Having seen a man coming through the ’badgir’ we prevented her from opening it but she did not hear what we said to her and has opened it. ’therefore, I had to ash one Sanad bin Abdullah to be a witness. On Friday night at 3.30 I came to the house, accompanied by Jabr bin ’Abdullah ad-hausari, in order to s^eeu and when X inspected the doors of the house and those of the room I saw that her room was locked from outside but there was light inside the room. I was*surprised to see this and had suspicion about her. I knocked the door but there was no reply. The doors of the house were locked from inside and I did not wigh to open her room when I had no one with me. I soon went out and called for Sanad bin ’Abdullah al Banqi who came with me. We opened her room but lound no one there, but while I was inside the room and Sanad was standing at the door oi the room, I noticed the feet and clothes of a man who was trying to come down through the badgir. I immediately ran after him and called for Sandd ( to help ) but I was only able to catch his clothes for he managed to be outside while I was inside the room holding his clothes. When Sanad reached me the man got himself set free, by leaving his clothes behind and was able to escape. I then left Sanad in the room and went out and called Jabr bin ’Abdullah ad-Lausari and asked both of them to witness. All this happenedhappened when the woman was not present in the house. Sanad then went out to his house and I closed all doors of our house an and made my wife and Jamilah, the wife of my brother, to sit in her ( Maryam’s ) room and watch. While they were sitting there the woman came from over the wall of the house and entered the room where my wife and Jamilah were sitting and turned them out from it. When I came up and ashed her how hew did she manage to enter, she replied that she entered by leaping over the wall. I also ashed her from wher^did she come at that time to which she said that she, together with a woman from Hura, came from some people who were playing drums. I submit for the information of the honourabe the Political Agent that we are from the respect acle families and it is not fit for us to do such things. On making enquiries, however we came to know that she was leading a bad life which is not good for our honour or that of her people. This woman is of immoral character and my father Ahmad Din Yusuf is now of unsound mind confined in the house. Therefore, I request that you will kindly call her before you and order her to go back to her people and I undertake to pay for her expenses to her country, as we do not like to live with a woman of this kind who is of immoral character. I and our family are also in danger for thethe reason that she brings outsiders to our house when we are sleeping. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 27; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 4-21; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled. A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: This file concerns an Aden-born twenty-five year old woman, Mariam bint Ahmed, and requests – made both by her brothers in Aden and by her Bahraini husband's son in Bahrain – for her to be repatriated to Aden. Mariam bint Ahmed's divorce, her former husband's death, and her unwillingness to return to Aden, are documented in the file. The file's principal correspondents are the following: the Civil Secretary, Aden; the Chief Commissioner, Aden; the Political Agent, Bahrain; the Assistant Political Agent, Bahrain; Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain; Salman Bin Hamad Al Khalifa [Shaikh Salmān bin Ḥamad Āl Khalīfah]. The file contains three items of correspondence that are written in Arabic.
